poem:
"Under the Gaze of a Rubicon Sunset"

Heart aching in Gaza, Tel Aviv,
Sana'a under a 6pm trumpet of sun, 
the Open Arms mound ocean waves— 
scarred waterways of human plight. 
Relief, like the sunrise, lingers
on the horizon where war did not sleep.
Aid is the cargo of hope,
cradled in the arms of evening, yet unbruised. 
Keep watch, the dawn brings promise.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Middle East crisis live: scores injured as aid warehouse is hit, says Unrwa 3.04pm GMT Closing summary It has gone 5pm in Gaza, Tel Aviv and Beirut, and 6pm in Sana’a. We will be closing this blog soon, but you can stay up to date on the Guardian’s Middle East coverage here. Here is a recap of the latest developments: The aid ship, the Spanish-flagged Open Arms, which left Cyprus yesterday, is expected to reach". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
